title: Innovation Hub - Internal Documentation
text:
Intro
This book has been created to document all the steps and decisions made on the implementation of the Innovation Hub (IH) for the Poverty & Inequality Platform (PIP).

title: 1  Introduction
text:
This is a book created from markdown and executable code.
See Knuth (1984) for additional discussion of literate programming.

1 + 1

[1] 2

title: Innovation Hub - Internal Documentation
text:
Objectives
The Innovation Hub intends to be a place to showcase experimental poverty and inequality measures, and analyze how these methodologies would compared to official PIP numbers.

title: Innovation Hub - Internal Documentation
text:
Requisites
Proposals submitted should be “generalizable”. This means, they must be applicable to/and produce estimates for “all” economies, the world, and world regions.
In order to be showcased in PIP’s Innovation Hub, Authors must submit the following outputs:

DATA: a.dta file with poverty rates ($2.15, $3.65 & $6.85 a day) and inequality estimates(?) for all economies, world and world regions.
Metadata:
Methodological note: a 1-2 pager summarizing the proposed methodology. Should be available for public use.

title: Innovation Hub - Internal Documentation
text:
The Innovation Hub

Objective
The Innovation Hub intends to be a place to showcase experimental poverty and inequality methodologies, and analyze how these alternative methods would compared to official PIP numbers.


Requisites
Proposals submitted should be “generalizable”. This means, they must be applicable to/and produce estimates for “all” economies, the world, and world regions.
In order to be showcased in PIP’s Innovation Hub, Authors must submit the following outputs:

DATA: a.dta file with poverty rates ($2.15, $3.65 & $6.85 a day) and inequality estimates(?) for all economies, world and world regions.
Metadata:
Methodological note: a 1-2 pager summarizing the proposed methodology. Should be available for public use.

title: Innovation Hub - Internal Documentation
text:
Objective
The Innovation Hub intends to be a place to showcase experimental poverty and inequality methodologies, and analyze how those alternative methods would compared to official PIP numbers.

title: Criteria
text:
Objective
The Innovation Hub intends to be a place to showcase experimental poverty and inequality methodologies, and analyze how those alternative methods would compared to official PIP numbers.

title: Criteria
text:
Requisites
Proposals submitted should be “generalizable”. This means, they must be applicable to/and produce estimates for “all” economies, the world, and world regions.
In order to be showcased in PIP’s Innovation Hub, Authors must submit the following outputs:

DATA: a.dta file with poverty rates ($2.15, $3.65 & $6.85 a day) and inequality estimates(?) for all economies, world and world regions.
Metadata:
Methodological note: a 1-2 pager summarizing the proposed methodology. Should be available for public use. This short document must contain link to actual paper.

title: Website
text:
Building the IH’s website. UI ideas:

Atlas of Sustainable Goals (scrolling down)
WB Development Economics (swiping right)
LAC Equity Lab (Tableau dashboard)
Our World in Data (cluster of dashboards “Interactive Charts on Poverty”)

FIGMA Prototypes:
https://www.figma.com/design/LKRqKOW0O4vuyeHYlcfx3Q/PIP’s-Innovation-Hub-(prototypes)?node-id=6-2&t=xQ2fpYCtVSJh2MMk-1
WB image collection:
https://www.flickr.com/photos/worldbank/albums/with/72157645353664062

title: IH’s 1st edition
text:
1. Poverty rates using Equivalence Scales
Source: Jolliffe, Dean, and Samuel Kofi Tetteh Baah. “Identifying the poor–Accounting for household economies of scale in global poverty estimates.” World Development 179 (2024): 106593.
Contact person: Samuel

title: IH’s 1st edition
text:
2. Poverty rates using Income-Consumption conversion
Source: Wollburg, Philip, Stephane Hallegatte, and Daniel Gerszon Mahler. “Ending extreme poverty has a negligible impact on global greenhouse gas emissions.” Nature 623, no. 7989 (2023): 982-986.
Contact person: Daniel

title: IH’s 1st edition
section: 3. Poverty rates scaled to National Accounts means (and consequently redrawn poverty lines)
text:
3. Poverty rates scaled to National Accounts means (and consequently redrawn poverty lines)
Source: Prydz, Espen Beer, Dean Jolliffe, and Umar Serajuddin. “Disparities in assessments of living standards using national accounts and household surveys.” Review of Income and Wealth 68 (2022): S385-S420.
Contact person: Espen

title: IH’s 1st edition
section: 4. Country-level poverty rates consistent with Urban/Rural definitions
text:
4. Country-level poverty rates consistent with Urban/Rural definitions
Source: Nakamura, Shohei, Pierre-Philippe Combes, Robin Moellerherm, Charlotte Robert, Mark Roberts, Benjamin Stewart, and Slava Yakubenko. “Where is Poverty Concentrated? New Evidence Based on Internationally Consistent Urban and Poverty Measurements” World Bank Policy Research Working Paper No. 10620 (2023).
Contact person: Shohei?
